content.title: Direct vs Indirect Revascularization
content.definition: Classification of revascularization strategies based on whether blood flow is restored directly to the angiosome containing the wound (direct) or via collateral pathways from adjacent angiosomes (indirect).

angiosome_concept.definition: Three-dimensional vascular territories supplied by specific source arteries
foot_angiosomes: Anterior tibial/dorsalis pedis: dorsum of foot
Posterior tibial: plantar heel and medial plantar
Peroneal: lateral ankle and heel (via collaterals)

direct_revascularization.definition: Revascularization of the artery directly supplying the angiosome with tissue loss
direct_revascularization.example: Treating plantar heel ulcer with posterior tibial revascularization

indirect_revascularization.definition: Revascularization of an artery supplying an adjacent angiosome
indirect_revascularization.example: Treating dorsal foot ulcer with peroneal revascularization

clinical_evidence.supporting_direct: Multiple studies show improved wound healing with direct revascularization

clinical_application.decision_making: Prioritize direct when possible, accept indirect when necessary

learning_objectives: Apply angiosome concept to wound healing
Understand when indirect revascularization is acceptable
clinical_pearls: Plantar wounds need posterior tibial (not AT or peroneal)
Any revascularization is better than none
Diabetic patients may have impaired collaterals
